>> But this learning over the course of generations through evolution
> can=

>> be classified as some "standard" kind of learning?
>> 
> 
> Yes it fall=
s under the banner of "evolutionary computation," which
> includes "genetic=
 algorithms," and more
> specifically, "neuroevolution," which means evolvi=
ng neural networks
> with evolutionary algorithms.  Much work has been done=
 in
> evolutionary computation in the last 40 years.  Most of these terms
>=
 appear in Wikipedia, if you want to see more.

There is an ambiguity in En=
glish (and probably most other languages) in the
terms used here. We think =
of learning across evolutionary time (where the
genome changes) and learnin=
g within a life (with no genomic change). The
same can be said of the word =
'adapting' and its synonyms.

I prefer to use the word 'intralife' and cont=
rast it with 'interlife.' Using
this terminology, BP is intralife and EC (e=
volutionary computation) is
generally interlife (unless evolution evolves t=
he capacity for intralife
learning, or is explicitly given it).
